Add dark mode variants to all components
Create static CSS and component rendering tests
Document component usage with markup examples

prompt_templates.title: Create a button

prompt_templates.title: Build a card
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a card component using css-development:create-component. Include title and description sub-elements with proper semantic naming.

prompt_templates.title: Add form styles

prompt_templates.prompt: Create a navigation component using css-development:create-component with proper atomic design organization, interactive states, and responsive behavior.

output_examples.input: Create a primary button component with hover effects and dark mode
output: Added dark mode variants for background and hover states
Created static CSS test verifying class exists
Documented usage with React and HTML examples

best_practices: Use semantic names that describe purpose, not appearance (use .button-primary not .btn-blue)
Always include dark mode variants from the start rather than adding them later
Check existing components first - compose over creating new classes
anti_patterns: Using utility-style names that couple styling to appearance (.text-blue, .card-sm)
Creating new classes when existing ones can be composed together
Skipping dark mode variants thinking they can be added later

faq.question: Does this skill work with plain CSS or only Tailwind?
faq.answer: The skill is designed for Tailwind projects using @apply but the semantic naming patterns apply to any CSS methodology.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with frameworks like Vue or Svelte?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill provides React examples but the CSS patterns and markup integration steps work with any framework.

faq.question: What if my project does not use dark mode?
faq.answer: You can still follow the skill but skip the dark mode variants. The skill will guide you on omitting them appropriately.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use with production code?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only provides guidance - all file modifications require your explicit approval before execution.

faq.question: Does this skill modify files automatically?
faq.answer: No. The skill guides you through steps but waits for your approval before making any file changes to your project.

faq.question: How is this different from coding the CSS manually?
faq.answer: The skill ensures consistency by enforcing naming conventions, dark mode requirements, and test coverage automatically.
